description: non-living, or a condition caused by a non-living agent (e.g. cold   temperature, nutrient deficiency)
a sexually-produced fungal spore; specific to the fungal lineage   Ascomycota
lacking sexual characteristics, or reproduction without the union of male and   female gametes (or two distinct organisms)

microscopic, single-celled organisms lacking a nucleus or membrane-bound   organelles and reproducing asexually; morphology usually spherical, spiral,   or rod shaped; ubiquitous in every habitat on Earth, including soil, water,   organic matter, and in/on the bodies of plants and animals

a.) a small lateral or terminal projection on the stem of a plant,   often enclosed by protective scales, from which shoots, leaves, or flowers   develop  b.) an undeveloped shoot, leaf, or flower  c.) an outgrowth from an organism that creates a new individual (asexual   reproduction)
a group of green pigments found in all plants that   are vital for the process of photosythesis, allowing plants to obtain   energy from light
an abnormal yellowing or whitening in green plant tissue due to insufficient   chlorophyll production
plant tissue that has lost its normal green coloration
Any small columnlike structure in various plants and   animals, often forming the central axis of development for the organism or an   anatomical structure
asexual, non-motile, fungal spores; when dispersed, they develop into   organisms genetically identical to the   parent (clone)
deliberately selected variants within a cultivated species that are grown for   horticultural and/or agricultural advantages
progressive death of shoots, branches, and roots that generally begins at the   tip and works back to the main body of the plant
the chain of events involved in disease development, including the stages of   development of the pathogen and the effect of the disease on the   host

a reproductive structure produced by some fungi that is distinct in   size, shape, and coloration for each species and contains spore-producing   structures; part of the sexual phase of a fungal life cycle (also known as a   sporocarp)
complex polysaccharidal substances formed by plant cells in reaction to   wounding or infection
an organism that is infected with or fed upon by a pathogenic or parasitic   organism
the various species or cell types that can act as a host to   a particular parasite or pathogen
the fine, branching tubes which make up the body (or mycelium) of a   multicellular fungus
a.) the pathogen or its part that causes infection of the host  b.) small amount of a microorganism that is transferred to a substrate   or a culture medium in order to propagate it
a state in which a host is infected with a pathogen but does not show   any symptoms
any defined area of living tissue that has been structurally modified as   a result of a disease or damaging process
an irregular pattern of indistinct light and dark areas

a change in any portion of the genetic material that causes a   permanent structural alteration of the DNA, frequently resulting in the   appearance of a new characteristic in an individual; usually detrimental, but   may be beneficial or neutral
mass of hyphae that constitutes the vegetative parts of a fungus (the   conspicuous part in most cases is the fruiting body of fungi)

a cell, group of cells, or tissue that has suffered a rapid destruction   and quick death; typically localized and may be caused by injury, radiation,   chemicals, toxic substances, or microbiological interactions
special glands of the leaf and fruit that produce essential   oils

an organism that lives on or in another organism (the host), obtaining   nourishment and shelter from the host; the host is often harmed and never   benefits from the presence of the parasite, but is rarely   killed
an organism, usually a microorganism, which causes disease by intimate   association with its host
bacterial strain or set of strains with the same or similar characteristics,   but differing in the species they infect or symptoms they produce;   pathovars are below the species rank taxonomically
(sing. phialoconidium): a conidium that develops from a   phialide
the plant vascular tissue that conducts products of photosynthesis and other   organic molecules such as hormones throughout the plant   body
asexual fruiting body of certain fungi, generally spherical or inversely   pearshaped, with an internal cavity containing conidia
a living plant, sometimes just the stump, with a healthy,   established root system, used for grafting a cutting or budding   from another plant; the grafted portion is called the   scion
rough, crust-like, diseased or injured area on the surface of a   plant
young shoot or twig of a plant that is grafted onto the rootstock of another   plant, usually a related species
symptom in which small diseased fragments of leaf tissue, usually dead, drop   out of the lesion, leaving small holes in their place

a.) small, walled reproductive body produced by non-flowing plants,   algae, fungi and some protozoans; usually microscopic and resistant to   desiccation and heat  b.) dormant, nonreproductive body formed by certain unicellular organisms,   especially bacteria, in response to harsh environmental   conditions
spreading internally throughout the plant body; may refer to a pathogen or   chemical
ability of a plant to sustain the effects of a disease or damaging agent   without dying or suffering serious injury or crop loss

a taxonomic category, a subdivision of species, consisting of naturally   occurring or selectively bred populations or individuals that differ from others   of the same species in certain minor but heritable traits
a specialized fungal hypha that produces   conidia
